assessment_comment: eDNA samples collected upstream and downstream of the crossing during the monitoring assessment.
dewatering_notes: Remedial works by MoTi in 2019 has backwatered the outlet pool level to match the pipe outlet elevation forming a deep outlet pool downstream. When stream is flowing - there will be continuous flow through the structure with cement/rock baffles present within the pipe.
velocity_notes: Although velocity at the time of assessment was low due to reduced flows, it was expected to exceed the burst swim capacity of all species, including chinook, during high flow conditions. Channel width upstream was up to three times greater, indicating substantially higher discharge during peak flows.
constriction_notes: Channel was significantly constricted due to the concrete armoring along the bottom of the pipe which reduced the effective width from approximately 4m to about 3.5m through the lower third of the structure.
substrate_notes: Five concrete baffles within the structure appeared damaged, likely from high flow events, and were retaining minimal substrate. Only the second baffle from the upstream end was effectively holding material. Water in the outlet pool was turbid, and significant accumulation of fines was expected due to low velocities.
riparian_notes: Does not appear as though there was any riparian planting as part of the remediation works
flow_depth_notes: Depths of flow are very shallow however they are comparable to flow depths currently seen upstream and downstream
stability_notes: The downstream backwatering structures composed of Newbury riffles appeared stable and undamaged since 2019. In contrast, the concrete boulder baffles inside the structure showed evidence of damage likely caused by high flow events following construction.
revegetation_notes: Although unverified, it does not appear as though there was any planting done as part of the project
cover_notes: The deep outlet pool is providing good pool cover for fish
maintenance_notes: The baffles within the structure need to be rebuilt to be the most effective

dewatering_notes: Channel appeared to be maturing well, with beaver activity backing up extended sections and creating high-quality chinook parr rearing habitat, including within the construction footprint.
velocity_notes: Due to all the beaver activity velocities are slow with some riffle sections connecting backwatered areas
constriction_notes: Channel within the riprap directly under the bridge is comparable width to upstream and downstream
substrate_notes: Substrate appears appropriate for stream and comparable within the footprint to upstream and downstream. Primarily fines and gravel.
riparian_notes: Upstream of the structure, numerous felled aspen trees indicated active beaver use. No shrub planting appeared to have been completed as part of the construction, and vegetation regrowth was minimal except along the lower margins of the riprap where natural cottonwood, dogwood, and willow establishment was occurring.
flow_depth_notes: Water depths were reasonable given the minimal flows at the time of assessment. Very shallow riffle areas were present, consistent with expected conditions under low flow.
stability_notes: Structure is stable with no evidence of any deterioration.
revegetation_notes: Rock armoring installed during construction was not planted and remained largely bare of vegetation. Within the construction footprint, some volunteer willow, cottonwood, dogwood, and rose were present, though cover was dominated by grass species likely seeded at the time of construction.
cover_notes: Cover had increased as a result of backwatering from beaver dams and the accumulation of large woody debris created by trees felled through beaver activity.
